qas.question: What kind of parapodia do burrowing annelids often have?

answers.text: ridges whose tips bear hooked chetae

qas.question: What type of annelids have limb-like parapodia?

answers.text: unjointed paired extensions of the body wall

plausible_answers.text: ridges whose tips bear hooked chetae

qas.question: What kind of parapodia do aerial annelids often have?
What type of annelids have dream-like parapodia?

plausible_answers.text: unjointed paired extensions of the body wall

qas.question: What are parapodia no longer considered?

context: Nearly all <a2_0>polychaetes<a2_0/> have parapodia that function as limbs, while other major annelid groups lack them. Parapodia are <a3_0><b7_0>unjointed paired extensions of the body wall<b7_0/><a3_0/>, and their muscles are derived from the circular muscles of the body. They are often supported internally by one or more large, thick chetae. The parapodia of burrowing and tube-dwelling <b6_0>polychaetes<b6_0/> are often just <a1_0><b5_0>ridges whose tips bear hooked chetae<b5_0/><a1_0/>. In active crawlers and swimmers the parapodia are often divided into large upper and lower paddles on a very short trunk, and the paddles are generally fringed with chetae and sometimes with cirri (<a0_0><b4_0>fused bundles of cilia<b4_0/><a0_0/>) and gills.
